Name: Sam Ntiro
General Info/biography: Margaret Trowell School of Fine Art; 1963 - Tanzanian High Commissioner to London; In July 1968, was Tz Commissioner for Culture

Name: Sheikh Amri Abedi
General Info/biography: First AFrican mayor of DSM, Minister for Community Development and National Culture at time of death

Name: Benjamin Mkapa
General Info/biography: Editor of The Nationalist, Managing editor daily news, sunday news, then became Nyerere's Press Secretary, then Foreign Minister, from 1995-2005 President

Name: Francis Khamisi
General Info/biography: Journalist and politician, worked with Oscar Watkins on Baraza, then set up other publications, political career focused on Coast region, before returning to edit Baraza 1961. East African regionalism - visit to Tanganyika early 40s. Presenter of 'Ubingwa wa Lugha' 1964/65

Name: Thomas Marealle
General Info/biography: Paramount chief of Chagga 1950s, 1960s - UN food and agriculture organisation

Name: Elimo Njau
General Info/biography: Artist and founder of Paa ya Paa Gallery in Nairobi

Name: Rebecca Njau
General Info/biography: One of Kenya's first women playwrights.  Notable works: The Scar (play), Ripples in the Pool (novel). Studied at Makerere College and attended the African Writers Conference in June 1962. Was married to Tanzanian visual artist Elimo Njau, with whom she ran Paa ya Paa Gallery in Nairobi during the 1960s and 1970s.

Name: Elvania Namukwaya Zirimu
General Info/biography: Ugandan playwright and dramaturgue. Founder of Ugandan theatre company Ngoma Players. Notable works include Keeping Up with the Mukasas, When the Hunchback Made Rain, and Snoring Strangers. Studied at Makerere University and was a regular contributor to Dhana. Married to academic and linguist Pio Zirimu.

Name: Micere Mugo
General Info/biography: Kenyan author, poet, playwright and academic. Studied at Makerere College and contributed to Penpoint. Political activist, fled Kenya in 1982, lived in Zimbabwe and later USA in exile. Notable works include Daughter of my People, Sing! (poetry collection), My Mother's Song and Other Poems (poetry collection), The Long Illness of Ex-Chief Kiti (play), and The Trial of Dedan Kimathi (play, co-authored with Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o)

Name: Barbara Kimenye
General Info/biography: Ugandan author and journalist. Wrote for Daily Nation as Uganda's first Black woman journalist. Notable works include Kalasanda, Kalasanda Revisited, Moses series, Gemstone Affair, and Beauty Queen.
Origin: British-born, of Haitian and English descent

Name: Grace Ogot
General Info/biography: Kenyan author, nurse, journalist, politician and women's activist. Worked for the BBC, represented Kenya to the UN, and was elected MP. Notable works include The Promised Land (novel), Land Without Thunder (short story collection), The Other Woman (short story collection), Miaha (novel - translated in English as The Strange Bride). She was on the editorial board of Busara, and contributed to magazines including Transition and East Africa Journal. Married to academic and historian Bethwel Ogot

Name: Marjorie Macgoye
General Info/biography: Kenyan author of British heritage. Notable works include Murder in Majengo (novel), Coming To Birth (novel), Victoria (novel), and Song of Nyarloka and other Poems (poetry collection).

Name: Rhoda Kalema
General Info/biography: Ugandan politician and civil society leader. Worked as a social worker and minister, active member of Uganda Council for Women

Name: Florence Lubega
General Info/biography: One of Uganda's first African women politicians to serve on the Legislative Council (LEGCO), and first woman MP. Lobbied for girls' education to the LEGCO.

Name: Joyce Mpanga
General Info/biography: One of Uganda's first African women politicians to serve on the LEGCO, later elected to parliament as part of Obote's first coalition government. Fled Uganda after 1966 Mengo crisis, returned in 1972. Remained active in education and politics, champion for girls' and women's rights.

Name: Rebecca Mulira
General Info/biography: Ugandan civil society and women's rights activist. Founded Uganda branch of YWCA. Active with Uganda Council for Women, young wives group, and Kampala City Council.

Name: Rose Mbowa
General Info/biography: Ugandan writer, actress and dramaturgue. Studied at Makerere College and contributed to Penpoint. Notable works include Ruin (poem), That Game (poem) and Mother Uganda and her Children. Starred as Mother Courage in Nalukalala, Ugandan rendition of Berthold Brecht's Mother Courage and her Children. Later Head of Department for Makerere's Department for Music, Dance and Drama. Actively promoted 'theatre for development' in rural Uganda

Name: Pumla Kisosonkole
General Info/biography: Ugandan politician, of South African heritage. First African woman on the Ugandan LEGCO, first African president of Ugandan Council for Women, president of the International Council of Women. Also represeted Uganda to UN.

Name: Noah Sempira
General Info/biography: Director of East African Literature Bureau

Name: Reuben Olembo
General Info/biography: Kenyan scientist; participated in Tom Mboya's airlifts

Name: Wilbert Chagula
General Info/biography: President/chairman of East African Academy, 1963-77; governor of East African Institute of Social and Cultural Affairs, Principal University College DSM. Later Minister in Tz Govt from 1970, In 1972 was Minister for Water Development and power. Bio here; https://www.nzdl.org/cgi-bin/library?e=d-00000-00---off-0unescoen--00-0----0-10-0---0---0direct-10---4-------0-0l--11-en-50---20-about---00-0-1-00-0--4----0-0-11-10-0utfZz-8-10&a=d&cl=CL2.3.5&d=HASH01768b0d11be94a36bd1a2.3

Name: Sayed Abidi
General Info/biography: Director of East African School of Librarianship, arrived in Uganda from India 1971, still living in Kampala

Name: Boloki Chango Machyo
General Info/biography: Economist, surveyor, activist

Name: Taban lo Liyong
General Info/biography: Part of the move to abolish the English Department at the University of Nairobi

Name: Kirunda Kivejinja
General Info/biography: Most recently advisor to Museveni, but early career in publishing and activism. Worked with Uganda Publishing House and Milton Obote Foundation

Name: Josephine Moraa Moikobu
General Info/biography: Part of Tom Mboya's airlifts

Name: Hilary Ng'weno
General Info/biography: Harvard graduate; part of Tom Mboya's airlifts; first African editor of Daily Nation February 1962, resigned 1965; founded Joe magazine in 1973; founder & editor of Weekly Review

Name: George Githii
General Info/biography: Kenyatta's press secretary, replaced Ng'weno as editor of Daily Nation 1965, 1968 resigned to go to Oxford for degree course, returned to edit after Boaz Omari's death in 1972. Resigned 1977.

Name: Ali Mazrui
General Info/biography: Academic, writer and public intellectual.  Despite being unsuccesful in effort to attend Makerere as a student, later returned to great effect as an academic.  He left East Africa for the United States and a highly successful academic career in 1974.

Name: Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o
General Info/biography: Kenyan novelist, academic and activist. Studied at Makerere University (1963) and University of Leeds (1964). Worked as a lecturer at the University of Nairobi, part of the movement to abolish the English Department. Imprisoned for sedition in 1977, later forced into exile. Notable works include The River Between (novel), Weep Not Child (novel), I Will Marry When I Want (play), The Black Hermit (play)

Name: Walter Rodney
General Info/biography: 1968 - exclusion order against him in Jamaica. Lecturer UDSM 1970 to at least 1975, How Europe Underdeveloped AFrica published 1973 by Bogie-L’Ouverture Publications and  Tanzania Publishing House. Articles in Sunday News in 1970 provoked protest Notes from British envoy.

Name: Boaz Omori
General Info/biography: Educated at Maseno, Alliance. 1954, Reporter, then Sub Editor for Baraza newspaper, column 'Panapo Moshi', 1959, to Taifa Leo, sub editor then Editor of Taifa Leo 1962. Early 1963 appointed eidtor in chief nation group, then First African chief Editor of Kenya broadcasting corporation from Jan 1964 - in this role in 1966. News Editor VOK. Became editor in chief of nation group in 1968. Died 1972 - editor in chief of Nation Group, appointed to IPI executive board. 1966 - Visit to India as News Editor VOK with Francis Khamisi and Walter Nyawanda.

Name: Sheikh Hyder el-Kindy
General Info/biography: Sauti ya Mvita - 1952. 1967 was President of Kenya Swahili Council

Name: Milton Obote
General Info/biography: Prime Minister & President of Uganda; student at Makerere

Name: Boloki Chango Machyo
General Info/biography: See Global Lives bio; academic at Makerere in 1969
Main Activity: Boloki Chango Machyo W’Obanda (1927-2013) | Another World? East Africa and the Global 1960s (globaleastafrica.org)

Name: Ebrahim Hussein
General Info/biography: Tanzanian playwright and poet. Author of Kinjeketile (1969) and other works. 1970 was Lecturer in Theatre ARts, University College DSM
